Graphical abstract Quantum chemistry calculations were performed to reveal the roles of the active oxygen species in the CO oxidation and the interactions between the gaseous molecules (CO, O2, CO2, etc.) and the active sites to design a highly active and low-temperature Mn/TiO2 catalyst. The results show that the Ti5a-O2b-Mn5c (TOM) coordination structure is the active center for the chemisorption of CO and O2. The dominant cycles were proposed over the TOM structure, which consist of three reaction stages, i.e., first CO oxidation → surface re-oxidation → second CO oxidation. Two kinds of active oxygen species, i.e., the lattice oxygen of TOM and the two atomic oxygen formed during the surface re-oxidation process, play critical roles in the dominant CO oxidation cycles. The energy barriers of the dominant oxidation cycles are lower than 50 kJ/mol, which explain well the high low-temperature activity of Mn/TiO2 catalyst for CO abatement. Keywords Mn/TiO2 catalyst CO oxidation Reaction pathway Active oxygen species 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide (CO) is a hazardous pollutant generated by the incomplete combustion of fossil fuels, solid wastes, etc., which is harmful to human health [1–3]. Catalytic oxidation is an important technique to reduce CO emission [4]. Late transition metals (LTMs) such as Pt, Pd, Rh, and Au, and LTM-doped catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity towards CO oxidation [5–9]. However, the high cost of LTMs has limited their wide application. In recent years, the catalysts composed of transition metals (Fe, Ni, Mn, Cu, Co, etc.) oxide composites have been extensively applied for the investigations of CO catalytic oxidation [10–17]. In particular, many experimental results have indicated that Mn-based catalysts showed excellent low-temperature activities for CO oxidation [18–20], owing to the outstanding properties caused by the interaction between MnO x and other metal oxides. Hence, Mn-based oxide composite catalysts may be potential candidates for CO removal at low temperatures. Among the Mn-based catalysts, the Mn/TiO2 catalyst has been studied broadly because of its perfect low-temperature redox activity for the treatments of many gaseous pollutants, such as nitric oxide (NO) [21–23], volatile organic compounds (VOCs) [24,25] and CO [26,27]. As for CO abatement, some experimental results revealed that the addition of MnO x on TiO2 could improve the performance of CO catalytic oxidation [26]. For example, it was reported that about 100 % removal of CO could be achieved at 200℃ [27]. This indicates that the Mn/TiO2 is a promising choice for CO abatement in many industrial processes, especially in conditions with low temperatures. However, to the best of our knowledge, there have been no relevant publications to reveal the mechanisms of CO catalytic oxidation over the surface of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation is a powerful tool to explore the detailed mechanisms of CO catalytic oxidation at atomic levels. Wang et al. investigated the catalytic oxidation of CO over Mn-doped CeO2(111) surface and found that the doping of Mn could help to form oxygen vacancies over the surface and increase the CeO2 surface activities for CO oxidation [28]. Luo et al. stated that the behaviors of CO oxidation over MnN3 doped grapheme with a double vacancy catalyst surface followed the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) mechanism, and the Mn atom was confirmed to be the major active site [29]. Besides, the presence of Mn species could significantly activate the OO bond over the graphene catalyst, which favored the electron migration over the surface and promoted the activity of CO catalytic oxidation [30]. In spite of the previous studies, there are still two unclear points for the CO catalytic oxidation, i.e., (1) how the interactions between gas molecules and the active sites on the Mn/TiO2 catalyst surface occur, (2) what the roles of active species are in the CO catalytic oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst surface. Therefore, the adsorption behaviors of gaseous molecules over the active sites and the effects on the CO catalytic oxidation were systematically investigated by DFT calculations over an Mn/TiO2(001) catalyst model in the present study. The active centers for the adsorption of CO and O2 were determined and all possible pathways for the following CO oxidation over the active sites were proposed. These results could provide fundamental information for understanding the reaction mechanisms of CO catalytic oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. 2 Methods 2.1 Theoretical methods The DMol3 package was applied to carry out all the spin-polarized calculations by the DFT method [31]. The Tkatchenko-Scheffler DFT long-range dispersion correction (DFT-D) [32] was incorporated in the DFT calculations. The exchange-correlation functions were treated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzernhof functional (PBE) [33]. A double numerical basis (DNP) was selected with a global orbital cutoff radius of 5.2 Å. The DFT semi-core pseudopotentials (DSPP) were applied for pseudo-potentials. 3 × 3×3 and 3 × 3×1 k-point meshes were used for bulk lattice and CO oxidation systems optimization, respectively. The convergence criteria in the value of total energy, maximum force, and maximum displacement were set at 1 × 10−5 Hartree, 2 × 10−3 Hartree/Å, and 5 × 10−3 Å, respectively. A Fermi smearing parameter of 0.008 Ha was applied to accelerate the convergence of self-consistent field in the calculations. To verify the effect of the Hubbard (U) parameter on the reaction energy profile of the Mn/TiO2 surface, a test was carried out, as shown in Table A1 in our supplementary materials (SM). The results indicates that PBE + U has no evident influence on the reaction energy profile. Hence, U was not incorporated in our calculations. The calculation methods mentioned above were firstly used to optimize the anatase TiO2 primary cell. The optimized bulk lattice constants are a = b = 3.776 Å and c = 9.486 Å, which are in good agreement with the experimental data of a = b = 3.782 Å and c = 9.502 Å [34]. All the gas-phase species (CO, CO2 and O2) were optimized as isolated molecules in a cubic crystal cell with constant of 10 Å. Adsorption energy (E ads) represents the interaction between the surface and the adsorbate, which is defined as follows. (1) E ads = E cat-mol− (E cat + E mol) Where Ecat-mol, E cat, and E mol represent the energies of the system after adsorption, the catalyst surface before adsorption, and the isolated adsorbed molecule, respectively. Besides, in order to determine the reaction pathways for CO catalytic oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst, transition states (TSs) were firstly fixed by a combination of linear synchronous transit (LST) and quadratic synchronous transit (QST) method. The Hessian elements were computed by displacing each atom in the model and computing a gradient vector, this built a complete second derivative matrix, which was used for vibrational frequencies. Meanwhile, the coarse-grained parallelization was used for the numerical displacement frequency calculation. The frequencies of the TSs were then calculated and analyzed to guarantee only one imaginary frequency. 2.2 Surface model of the Mn/TiO2 catalyst TiO2 has different crystal structures [35], it is very important to determine a suitable model [36]. According previous study, anatase (001) is more favorable than anatase (101) for oxidation reaction [37,38]. Meanwhile, the most reactive (001) facet of anatase TiO2 is commonly used in previous theoretical calculations [39,40], which was also considered in this study. For the Mn/Ti catalyst, MnO x species are highly dispersed on the anatase TiO2 surface, and the Mn atom mainly exists in +4 state as the same periodic element as Ti [41]. Hence in this study, an Mn atom was intercalated into the TiO2 surface. Based on the previous investigations, a (3 × 3) TiO2(001) supercell model with a 9-layer slab was erected with a 15 Å vacuum region to avoid the interactions between two slabs, and an Mn atom replaced a Ti atom of TiO2 surface to form a model of Mn/TiO2(001). The similar metal-doped TiO2(001) models were also applied in the previous DFT studies [41–44]. For the stability of Mn doping, the total system energies of the Mn doped surface (E sur) and the Mn doped subsurface (E subsur) were calculated. The result indicates Mn is more stable on the Mn/TiO2 surface than subsurface, and the detailed information is available in SM. The Ti atoms and the doped Mn atom are all +4 state in the Mn/TiO2 catalyst model, the judgement of the surface atoms valence states is provided in SM, as shown in Fig. A2. The structure of the erected Mn/TiO2(001) catalyst model is shown in Fig. 1 . Four adsorption sites were taken into consideration in calculations, i.e., 5-fold Ti atom (Ti5a at point a), 2-fold O atom (O2b at point b), 5-fold Mn atom (Mn5c at point c), and 3-fold O atom (O3d at point d), respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of the Mn/TiO2(001) surface The properties of the Mn/TiO2 surface are important for the adsorption and reaction of gaseous molecules. Hence, the effect of Mn doping on the TiO2 surface was firstly determined and discussed. The geometric parameters of the Mn/TiO2(001) surface with four adsorption sites (a, b, c, and d) are recorded in Table 1 . The adsorption sites of TiO2(001) are the same as that of the Mn/TiO2(001), as shown in Fig. 1. Meanwhile, more detailed information of all surface bond lengths is available in our SM. The length of Ti5a-O2b (2.241 Å) and Mn5c-O2b (1.739 Å) on the Mn/TiO2(001) surface are changed apparently after Mn doping, due to the differences in electronic properties between the Mn atom and the Ti atom. Whereas, the Ti5c-O3d bond length (1.932 Å) of TiO2 is close to the Mn5c-O3d bond length (1.948 Å). Other corresponding surface chemical bonds are also changed slightly, as shown in Fig. A1 in SM. According to the analysis of surface bond lengths, there are two obvious changed chemical bonds (Ti5a-O2b and Mn5c-O2b) after introducing an Mn atom into the TiO2(001). In addition, a Ti5a-O2b-Mn5c (TOM) coordination structure composed of the two bonds can be found over the Mn/TiO2(001) surface. According to previous studies, the Mn site is generally the major active site for CO catalytic oxidation in various catalysts [28–30,45]. Meanwhile, a stable structure of metal-oxygen coordination can promote the performance of CO oxidation apparently [7,46]. Hence, it can be deduced that the formation of the TOM coordinate structure can be beneficial for improving the activity of the Mn/TiO2 surface, which will be further investigated in the present study. In order to disclose the effects of Mn doping on the electronic properties of the catalyst surface, the partial density of states (PDOS) maps of Ti5a, O2b Mn5c, the Mn/TiO2 and pristine TiO2 are analyzed, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). The Mn5c-d orbit is strongly hybridized with O2b-p orbit at the peak −5.69 eV, −4.86 eV, −2.82 eV, −0.95 eV and 0.15 eV. In contrast, the Ti5a-d orbit is slightly hybridized with O2b-p orbit only at the peak −5.04 eV, which indicates that the interaction between O2b and Mn5c is stronger than that of the O2b-Ti5a bond, resulting in the shorter bond length of Mn5c-O2b than that of Ti5a-O2b. The electron density difference (EDD) of the catalyst surface is usually used to elucidate the charge transfer and the redox characteristics during the chemical reaction process [47]. Fig. 2 presents the EDD of the TiO2(001) and the Mn/TiO2(001) catalyst models, with the charge accumulation and depletion regions displayed in red and blue, respectively. The charge accumulation and depletion regions between O2b and Mn5c are much larger than those between O2b and Ti5a for Mn/TiO2, indicating that the charge distribution is notably altered in the TOM structure compared to that of TiO2 surface. This proves that the charge transfer among the atoms of the TOM structure occurs significantly, which is helpful for improving the surface activity of the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. Fig. 3 displays the electrostatic potential (ESP) of the TiO2 and the Mn/TiO2 catalyst models, which reflects the surface reactivity. Generally, the active site with a negative value of ESP is favorable to accept the electrophilic attack, while the positive ESP site is beneficial for the nucleophilic attack [48]. The ESP values around the atoms on the catalyst surface are positive, suggesting that the effect of the concentrated nucleus dominates the dispersed electrons and the adsorption of nucleophilic such as CO and O2. Compared with the ESP of TiO2 surface, the ESP of Mn/TiO2 surface changes obviously, which is owing to the charge transfer among surface atoms after Mn doping, as shown in Fig. 2 (b) and (c). In the TOM structure, the positive ESP values of the Ti5a site are larger than the O2b and Mn5c atoms, which suggests that the Ti5a site facilitates the adsorption of CO and O2 molecules. In conclusion, a TOM coordinate structure is formed on the Mn/TiO2 catalyst surface after Mn doping, and the strong charge transfer among the atoms of the TOM coordinate structure is determined, which promotes the adsorption of the gaseous molecules (CO and O2) and increases reaction activity of the catalyst surface. 3.2 CO and O2 adsorption on the Mn/TiO2(001) surface In order to explore the detailed mechanisms of CO catalytic oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 surface, the adsorption of O2 and CO on the four different sites (Ti5c, O2b, Mn5c, and O3d) were firstly investigated. As for the CO adsorption with C-end or O-end on the Mn/TiO2 surface, four corresponding stable structures are displayed in Fig. 4 . The most stable configure is 1C with the adsorption energy of -170.49 kJ/mol. The distance from C to Ti5a is 1.833 Å. In addition, CO is adsorbed on the O2b site (1D) and -97.86 kJ/mol heat is released. For the 1A and 1B configures, C and O atoms of CO are both adsorbed on the Mn5c site with similar adsorption energies, respectively. The adsorption energies range from −88.58 to −170.49 kJ/mol, which indicates that the adsorption of CO molecule on the Mn/TiO2(001) is chemisorption [49]. The results of O2 adsorption over the Mn/TiO2 surface are presented in Fig. 5 . Two stable configures are obtained, i.e., 2A and 2B. The adsorption energies are -92.43 kJ/mol (2A) and -202.79 kJ/mol (2B), respectively, which indicates that the O2 adsorption on the Ti5a site is more stable than that on the Mn5c site. In 2B configure, O2 is adsorbed on the Ti5a site in parallel. The distances between the two O atoms of the adsorbed O2 and the Ti5a atom are the same (1.989 Å). The distance from O to Mn5c is 1.842 Å in 2A configure. The adsorption of O2 over the Mn/TiO2 surface belongs to chemisorption because of the relatively high adsorption energies of the two stable structures. As shown in Figs. 4 and 5, the main active adsorption sites for CO and O2 are the Ti5a, O2b, and Mn5c, which are consistent with the findings suggested by property analyses in section 2.1. Meanwhile, the adsorption of CO and O2 on the TiO2(001) surface is also provided in SM, as shown in Figs. A2 and A3. The results show that the adsorption energies of CO and O2 on TiO2 surface are lower than those on the Mn/TiO2 surface, which indicates that Mn doping can enhance the interaction between adsorbed molecules and the catalyst surface. Based on the above illustrations, it can be confirmed that the TOM coordinate structure on the Mn/TiO2 surface is a potential active center for adsorption and following oxidation reactions. 3.3 CO oxidation mechanisms on the Mn/TiO2 surface 3.3.1 Comparative analysis of CO oxidation with adsorbed O2 and lattice O According to the previous studies, the adsorbed O2 and the lattice oxygen play important roles in the process of CO catalytic oxidation [50,51]. Based on the discussions in Section 3.2, two reaction pathways are proposed for CO catalytic oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 surface, as given in Fig. 6 . Since the structure (2B) formed by an adsorbed O2 is slightly more stable than the structure (1C) formed by an adsorbed CO at the same Ti5a sites, pathway 1 is proposed, in which the oxidation of CO over the Mn/TiO2 starts from an adsorbed O2. Besides, CO is also steadily adsorbed on the Ti5a site of the Mn/TiO2 surface with a structure as 1C in Fig. 6. Due to the strong interaction and the obvious charge transfer among the O2b and Mn5c atoms, pathway 2 is also proposed, in which the adsorbed CO firstly reacts with the active O (O2b). In order to determine the favorable pathway of CO oxidation on the Mn/TiO2 surface, the two pathways were compared and discussed systematically. Four ERSs are included in pathway 1, i.e., O2 adsorption, CO adsorption, CO → CO2, and CO2 desorption. Firstly, an O2 molecule is adsorbed on the Ti5a site of the Mn/TiO2 catalyst surface (see IM1) with 202.79 kJ/mol heat released. Then, CO adsorption is exothermic with 8.08 kJ/mol. In the third step (CO → CO2), the O atom close to the C atom (the distance from O to C is 3.446 Å, see IM2) reacts with the CO atom to generate a CO2 molecule (IM3). The distance from C atom to O atom decreases gradually: 3.446 Å (IM2) → 1.821 Å (TS1) → 1.177 Å (IM3). This step of CO oxidation is exothermic by 220.06 kJ/mol and activated by 187.10 kJ/mol, which is the rate-determining step (RDS). Finally, CO2 desorption from the catalyst surface is endothermic by 5.78 kJ/mol. A new structure (FS1) with two atomic oxygen (O1 and O2) on the Mn/TiO2 surface is formed, as shown in Fig. 6. In this pathway, a CO reacts with the adsorbed O2 to generate a CO2 molecule, which follows Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism [52]. Pathway 2 consists of three ERSs, i.e., CO adsorption, CO → CO2, and CO2 desorption. At first, CO is chemically adsorbed on the Ti5a site (see IM4). The energy released from CO adsorption is −170.49 kJ/mol. Then, the adsorbed CO molecule is oxidized to a CO2 molecule. The distance from C to O2b decreases gradually: 2.568 Å (IM4) → 1.676 Å (TS3) → 1.188 Å (IM5). The step of CO oxidation is an exothermic reaction with an energy barrier of 25.07 kJ/mol and the reaction heat is 85.07 kJ/mol. At last, CO2 desorption from the catalyst surface requires 71.38 kJ/mole heat, which is the RDS. An oxygen vacancy (Ov) is produced on the Mn/TiO2 surface in this step, as FS2 displayed in Fig. 6. In this pathway, the adsorbed CO reacts with a lattice oxygen to generate a CO2 molecule, which follows Mars-van-Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [53]. Based on the above results, the energy barrier of pathway 2 (25.07 kJ/mol) is much lower than that of pathway 1 (187.10 kJ/mol), as shown in Fig. 6. This illustrates that pathway 2 is dominant in the process of CO catalytic oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. In addition, compared with the adsorbed O2 on the Ti5a site in TOM coordinate structure, the lattice oxygen is activated after Mn doping and the oxidation of CO with the lattice oxygen is dominant. Furthermore, the adsorbed O2 is found to be inert for CO oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst because of the relatively high energy barrier. The results are in good agreement with the conclusion obtained by Boningari et al. [54]. To confirm the activity for CO oxidation over TiO2(001) surface, a calculation on the CO reaction with the adsorbed O2 (pathway A1) and the lattice O (pathway A2) was conducted, as shown in Fig. A3. The results indicate that CO is hardly oxidized by the surface oxygen species over the TiO2(001) surface. Therefore, only Mn/TiO2 was applied for investigation of the mechanism of CO oxidation in the present calculations. At the end of the dominant pathway 2, a reduced Mn/TiO2 surface is formed when the bridging O2b atom is consumed by CO during the oxidation process, leaving an oxygen vacancy (Ov) at the O2b site, as FS2 in Fig. 6. 3.3.2 Re-oxidation of the reduced Mn/TiO2 surface The reduced catalyst surface with an Ov can be re-oxidized by an O2 molecule [55]. Therefore, the re-oxidation process of the reduced Mn/TiO2 surface was further considered, as displayed in Fig. 7 . The whole re-oxidation process includes two ERSs: O2 adsorption → O2 dissociation. Firstly, an molecular O2 is chemically adsorbed over the reduced Mn/TiO2 catalyst surface, producing a superoxide (O2 −) molecule [55]. The O2 adsorption process releases 243.58 kJ/mol heat. Then, the formed O2 − molecule on the Ov site dissociates into two O atoms (see FS3), thereby accomplishing the re-oxidation process over the Mn/TiO2 surface. Consequently, the reduced Mn/TiO2 catalyst surface is re-oxidized into a new structure with two atomic oxygen (O1 and O2), see FS3. The distance of adsorbed O2 molecule grows gradually: 1.412 Å (IM6) → 1.652 Å (TS3) →2.562 Å (FS3). It is noteworthy that the structure formed by O2 dissociation on reduced surface (FS3) is the same as the structure FS1 in the pathway 1 in Fig. 6. The O2 dissociation process is an exothermic process with a slight energy barrier of 15.80 kJ/mol and exothermic of −52.89 kJ/mol. The results are consistent with the previous oxygen isotopic labeling studies [54], the presence of gaseous oxygen provides an additional driving force for the rapid and complete oxidation of the Mn/TiO2 surface. The atomic oxygen species (O1 and O2) formed by a dissociative O2 during the re-oxidation process or the CO oxidation process of pathway 1 can be easily depleted by a CO to generate a CO2 molecule [56], which will be further investigated in the following section. 3.3.3 Further catalytic oxidation of CO on the re-oxidized Mn/TiO2 surface Fig. 8 shows the detailed CO oxidation process initiated from the O + surface configure, which is the same as FS3 in Fig. 7 and FS1 in Fig. 6. Different channels for CO oxidation are provided by the two reaction pathways (pathway 3 and pathway 3ʹ) on the re-oxidized Mn/TiO2 surface. Pathway 3 starts from CO adsorbed on O1 (see IM7), while pathway 3ʹ is initialed from CO adsorbed on the O2 site (see IM7ʹ), as shown in Fig. 8. Pathway 3 includes three ERSs: CO adsorption, CO → CO2, and CO2 desorption. At first, CO adsorbed on the O1 site is exothermic by 16.52 kJ/mol, as IM7. Then, an energy barrier of 48.07 kJ/mol is required, and during the oxidation process of CO into CO2 with an obviously exothermic energy of 220.06 kJ/mol. The distance from C to O1 decreases gradually: 2.923 Å (IM7) → 1.846 Å (TS4) → 1.181 Å (IM8). Finally, CO2 desorption is controlled by an external energy of 82.16 kJ/mol (see FS4), which is the RDS. The Mn/TiO2 catalyst surface is restored to its initial state. In addition, pathway 3ʹ is initialed from the CO adsorbed on O2 site, which also includes three ERSs as pathway 3. Firstly, CO is adsorbed on the O2 site of the catalyst surface with 14.06 kJ/mol heat released, as IM7ʹ. Next, the oxidation of CO into CO2 requires an energy barrier of 23.01 kJ/mol and is exothermic by 276.83 kJ/mol. Finally, the CO2 desorption process is dominated by an extra energy of 115.92 kJ/mol (see FS4), which is the RDS. The surface of the catalyst is recovered to its initial state. As described above, the energy barrier of pathway 3ʹ (23.01 kJ/mol) is lower than that of pathway 3 (48.07 kJ/mol), as shown in Fig. 8, which indicates that the O2 is more active than O1 for CO oxidation. Whereas, CO2 desorption energy of pathway 3ʹ (115.92 kJ/mol) is higher than that of pathway 3 (82.16 kJ/mol), which demonstrates that CO2 formed on the O2 site is harder to desorb from the catalyst surface than CO2 formed on the O1 site. Both RDSs of the two pathways are the final step (CO2 desorption), and the desorption energies are much higher than their energy barriers. Based on the above results, it can be concluded that both pathways are favorable for CO oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. The surfaces of the catalysts are restored to the original Mn/TiO2, and the CO oxidation cycles on the catalyst surfaces are completed. 3.4 Complete catalytic reaction scheme Based on the CO oxidation pathways proposed in Section 3.3, the catalytic oxidation processes of CO over the Mn/TiO2 surface can be illustrated by an overall reaction formula: 2CO + O2 → 2CO2. Besides, to determine the comprehensive reaction mechanisms of CO oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the relationships of the different reaction pathways in Figs. 6–8 are analyzed in-depth. The holonomic catalytic oxidation cycles that can generate the exact stoichiometry are proposed from the present DFT-derived calculations, as displayed in Fig. 9 . There are four possible reaction cycles for CO oxidation, as presented in Fig. 9. Cycle 1 is composed of pathway 1 (steps 12–15) in Fig. 6 and pathway 3 (steps 6–8) in Fig. 8. Cycle 2 is composed of pathway 1 (steps 12–15) in Fig. 6 and pathway 3ʹ (steps 9–11) in Fig. 8. Cycle 3 consists of pathway 2 in Fig. 6, the re-oxidation process (steps 4–5) in Fig. 9, and pathway 3 (steps 6–8) in Fig. 8. Cycle 4 consists of pathway 2 (steps 1–3) in Fig. 6, the re-oxidation process (steps 4–5) in Fig. 9, and pathway 3ʹ (steps 9–11) in Fig. 8. The RDSs of cycle 1 and cycle 2 are the first CO oxidation step. Whereas, the RDSs of cycle 3 and cycle 4 are the final CO2 dissociation steps. The energy barrier of the first oxidation step is 187.01 kJ/mol (cycles 1 and 2), which is much higher than that of the RDSs of cycle 3 (82.16 kJ/mol) and cycle 4 (115.92 kJ/mol). Therefore, CO oxidation reactions are preferred through cycle 3 and cycle 4, rather than cycle 1 and cycle 2. Our calculation results are coincident with previous experiment investigation results from Boningari et al. [54], that CO is not favorable to react with the gas phase oxygen to form CO2, but tends to react with the lattice oxygen of the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. According to the dominant cycles (cycles 3 and 4) for CO catalytic oxidation, the whole reaction process over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst can be divided into three stages including eight steps: first CO oxidation, surface re-oxidation, and second CO oxidation, as shown in Fig. 9. In the first CO oxidation stage (steps 1–3), it is believable that the lattice oxygen (O2b) is necessary for CO oxidation into CO2. Meanwhile, a CO2 molecule is generated and emitted into the flue gas, leaving a vacancy at the O2b site over the catalyst surface. Then, the reduced catalyst surface formed in the first CO oxidation process is oxidized by a molecular oxygen (steps 4–5), which only needs 15.80 kJ/mol heat to form an Mn/TiO2 surface with two atomic O, and is beneficial for the next CO oxidation process. In the second CO oxidation (steps 6–8 or steps 9–11), the atomic O (O1 or O2) is consumed by a CO molecule to generate a CO2 molecule. The final steps of CO desorption are the RDSs of the two cycles. After CO2 desorption, the catalyst surfaces are recovered to their initial states (step 8 or step 11). The stoichiometry of CO catalytic oxidation cycles is gained by coupling two CO oxidation stages and a surface re-oxidation stage. In order to probe into the deep mechanisms during the whole CO oxidation of dominant cycles, a sketch about the evolution of active oxygen species over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst surface is plot in Fig. 10 . At the same time, an Mn-assisted MvK mechanism is suggested in our study, the whole oxidation cycles are similar to the previous investigations [53]. The Mn doping makes the bridge O (O2b) an active oxygen. The active lattice O is important for the first CO oxidation, which follows the MvK mechanism. The first CO oxidation stage is similar to the results found by Behm et al. [57]. In the surface re-oxidation stage, two active oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) are formed by O2 dissociation adsorption at the Ov site. The active oxygen species (O1 or O2) are consumed by CO during the second CO oxidation stage, which also follows the MvK mechanism. The CO oxidation cycle on the Mn/TiO2 surface is completed along with the second generated CO2 desorption. At the same time, the Mn/TiO2 surface is restored to its original structure. In the complete dominant cycles for CO oxidation, CO2 desorption exhibits relatively higher energy consumption compared to CO oxidation and surface re-oxidation, as presented in Fig. 9. Therefore, the RDSs are CO2 desorption. To further confirm the outstanding CO removal performance of the Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the energy barriers of CO oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 surface are compared to those of CO oxidation over other catalyst surfaces, i.e., Pd/CeO2 [8], Ni1/FeO x [58] and La0.8Sr0.2CoO3(LSCO) [59]. These catalysts have been proved to be excellent for CO emission control at low temperatures. The energy barriers of CO oxidation are 61.75–72.36 kJ/mol over Ni1/Fe2O3(001), 56−63 kJ/mol over Pd/CeO2(100) surface, and 78.15 kJ/mol over LSCO(110) surface. Due to the low energy barriers (less than 50 kJ/mol) of CO oxidation and surface re-oxidation, the Mn/TiO2 can be a low-temperature catalyst for CO treatment in flue gas, which has been confirmed in previous experimental studies (100 % CO conversion bellow 200 ℃) [26,27]. 4 Conclusions In this research, the detailed reaction mechanisms of CO catalytic oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst were studied in-depth by DFT calculations. The results indicate that the adsorption of CO and O2 on the Mn/TiO2 catalyst is controlled by the chemisorption mechanism. The TOM structure formed on the Mn/TiO2 surface is the main active center for CO and O2 adsorption, which is also responsible for the CO catalytic oxidation. Four reaction cycles were proposed and discussed, and the cycles 3 and 4 in which CO firstly reacts with the lattice oxygen (O of TOM structure) over the Mn/TiO2 surface are more favorable. What is more, three reaction stages are included in the two dominant cycles: i.e., first CO oxidation (this process follows MvK mechanism) → surface re-oxidation → second CO oxidation (this process also follows MvK mechanism). Moreover, the lattice oxygen of TOM and the atomic oxygen formed by O2 dissociation during the surface re-oxidation process play key roles in the two oxidation stages. An Mn-assisted MvK reaction is recommended for CO oxidation over the Mn/TiO2 surface. The RDSs are the final CO2 desorption from the surface. The low energy barriers (25.07 kJ/mol for the first CO oxidation, 15.80 kJ/mol for the re-oxidation process, 48.07 kJ/mol of cycle 3, and 23.01 kJ/mol of cycle 4 for the second CO oxidation) make the Mn/TiO2 a prospective low-temperature catalyst for the CO abatement. coredata.dc:description: Quantum chemistry calculations were performed to reveal the roles of the active oxygen species in the CO oxidation and the interactions between the gaseous molecules (CO, O2, CO2, etc.) and the active sites to design a highly active and low-temperature Mn/TiO2 catalyst. The results show that the Ti5a-O2b-Mn5c (TOM) coordination structure is the active center for the chemisorption of CO and O2. The dominant cycles were proposed over the TOM structure, which consist of three reaction stages, i.e., first CO oxidation → surface re-oxidation → second CO oxidation. Two kinds of active oxygen species, i.e., the lattice oxygen of TOM and the two atomic oxygen formed during the surface re-oxidation process, play critical roles in the dominant CO oxidation cycles. The energy barriers of the dominant oxidation cycles are lower than 50 kJ/mol, which explain well the high low-temperature activity of Mn/TiO2 catalyst for CO abatement.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical insights into the roles of active oxygen species in heterogeneous oxidation of CO over Mn/TiO2 catalyst
